sentence.Network_en: Her government never really shook off the taint of corruption.
sentence.Network_cn: 她的政府从来没有真正摆脱掉腐败的阴影。

sentence.Network_en: Rancid oil will taint the flavour.
Bad books will taint the young mind.
sentence.Network_cn: 坏书会毒害年青人的思想.

derivation.yuyuan_name: Middle English (as a verb in the sense 'convict, prove guilty'): partly from Old French teint 'tinged', based on Latin tingere 'to dye, tinge'; partly a shortening of attaint

entry.tran: 玷污，毁坏，损害，败坏(地位、名誉)
entry.def: If a person or thing is tainted by something bad or undesirable, their status or reputation is harmed because they are associated with it.

example.ex: Opposition leaders said that the elections had been tainted by corruption.
example.tran: 反对派领导人说，选举中存在舞弊现象。

example.ex: ...a series of political scandals that has tainted the political stars of a generation.
example.tran: 令一整代政治明星声名染上污点的一系列政治丑闻

entry.def: A taint is an undesirable quality which spoils the status or reputation of someone or something.

example.ex: Her government never really shook off the taint of corruption...
example.tran: 她的政府从来没有真正摆脱掉腐败的阴影。

example.ex: She could smell the taint of sin in the most innocent of passions.
example.tran: 哪怕是再纯真的恋情她也能从中嗅出罪恶的味道。

entry.def: If an unpleasant substance taints food or medicine, the food or medicine is spoiled or damaged by it.

example.ex: Rancid oil will taint the flavour.
...blood tainted with the AIDS and hepatitis viruses.
example.tran: 被艾滋病毒和肝炎病毒污染的血液

means.word_mean: 1. place under suspicion or cast doubt upon;
2. contaminate with a disease or microorganism

means.word_mean: 使腐坏, 污染, 玷污, 败坏, 损害(某人的)名誉

sentences.en: His political reputation is tainted by the matter.
sentences.cn: 这件事玷污了他的政治声誉。

sentences.en: He was considered tainted by association with the corrupt regime.
sentences.cn: 他因与腐败政府有牵连而名誉受损。

sentences.en: Meat taints readily in hot weather.
